questions_and_answers.question: What methodologies are being used by the Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) Afghanistan to quantify and understand mobility dynamics at Afghanistan's borders?
questions_and_answers.updated_retrieved_answer: DTM Afghanistan's Flow Monitoring activity uses two interlinked exercises to quantify and understand mobility dynamics at Afghanistan's borders[11]. questions_and_answers.question: How is the World Food Programme (WFP) responding to the recent floods in Afghanistan, and what are the immediate and long-term strategies being implemented to support affected communities?
questions_and_answers.updated_retrieved_answer:
The World Food Programme (WFP) is responding to the recent floods in Afghanistan with both immediate and long-term strategies[64][64][65][63][63].

**Immediate Response:**
WFP activated its contingency response plan, triggered by its early warning system, and prepositioned food stocks in Herat and Mazar ahead of the rains[66][65]. WFP's area office mobilized within three hours of the floods to dispatch and distribute fortified biscuits and lipid-based nutrient supplements (LNS) for blanket distribution in all affected locations[67]. Immediate distributions to accessible affected households included high-energy biscuits, nutritional supplements, and subsidized bread rations[66][67]. Blanket food assistance has been distributed to affected populations in all currently accessible areas[68]. By the end of last week, WFP started providing food rations and cash assistance where markets were functional[64]. From May 15, WFP initiated multi-purpose cash assistance of AFN 6,400 (USD 87.7) to flood-affected populations, collaborating with partners on joint distributions[68]. WFP is also erecting and replacing rub-halls (mobile storage units) to serve as hubs, setting up new rub-halls for storage, and sending food trucks to a second hub[68]. Joint Assessment teams are in the field reporting on priority locations, scale, and impact[65].

**Long-term Strategies:**
Following initial distributions, WFP plans to provide food and nutrition assistance with a 100 percent ration for two months, followed by a reduced distribution at 50 percent for the remaining four months[66][67]. Resilience activities will be incorporated into the recovery program, targeting affected communities to mediate further loss[67]. WFP has called for an additional $14.5 million to assist flood-affected people with "emergency food and nutrition assistance and resilience-building projects"[69]. WFP is investing in climate adaptation projects, designed and built by communities, to shield them from the impacts of the climate crisis, including protective walls, dams, and irrigation canals[64].

questions_and_answers.question: What are the specific challenges faced by families like Hanifa's in Behsood e Markazi district during the winter, and how is cash distribution being utilized to address these challenges?
questions_and_answers.updated_retrieved_answer:
Families like Hanifa's in the Behsood e Markazi district face a dire economic situation due to a lack of job opportunities for women[70]and significant challenges coping with the harsh winter[70]. Her son, who is the family's caretaker, can only work for approximately three to four months a year, which must sustain them through the entire winter[71]. During winter, he is unemployed, and the family relies on support from relief agencies and other villagers[72]. Most residents in this remote, mountainous district live below the poverty line and lack access to basic needs[72]. Despite owning agricultural plots, they struggle to afford basic winter necessities due to limited opportunities and long winters that prevent them from earning sufficient incomes[72]. Hanifa's 90-year-old mother-in-law is gravely ill and requires a warm room and winter clothes[71].

Cash distribution is utilized to address these challenges by providing emergency support for winterisation needs[71]. People in Need, with funding from the Afghanistan Humanitarian Fund, distributed cash for winterisation assistance to nearly 13,000 people in 51 villages and 6 districts in Maidan Wardak, Central Afghanistan[71]. Hanifa's family received cash after their home was surveyed and their financial situation and challenges, including her mother-in-law's need for a warm room and winter clothes, were assessed[71]. The World Food Programme (WFP) also initiated multi-purpose cash assistance (AFN 6,400 / USD 87.7) to flood-affected populations, designed to complement the average income of Afghani households and enable them to meet their essential needs[73]. The "Goodness Train" initiative, organized by Trkiye's Disaster and Emergency Management Authority (AFAD), is contributing to the humanitarian response in Afghanistan by delivering aid to flood victims[74]. This campaign was launched amid Afghanistan's calls for international aid[75]. The train carries an assortment of humanitarian aid collected by AFAD and 17 nongovernmental organizations (NGOs)[74]. Trkiye had previously sent emergency aid by plane[75]. The "Goodness Train" series of campaigns for Afghanistan began after the 2022 turmoil[75].

The types of aid prioritized on this train include 600 tents, food, hygiene kits, beds, and blankets[74]. In total, the train carries 619 tons of aid[74].

74.context: title: Trkiye sees off another aid train for flood-hit Afghanistan  content: The "Goodness Train" organized by Trkiye's Disaster and Emergency Management Authority AFAD departed from Ankara's main train station on Tuesday. The train carries an assortment of humanitarian aid collected in a campaign by AFAD and 17 nongovernmental organizations NGOs for flood victims in Afghanistan.This is the 20th such train carrying aid for the Asian country whose economy is in tatters. The train's load includes 600 tents, food, hygiene kits, beds and blankets. In total, it carries 619 tons of aid.Deputy Interior Minister Mnir Karalolu, AFAD Chair Okay Memi and representatives of Turkish charities attended a ceremony to see off the train.
74.title: Trkiye sees off another aid train for flood-hit Afghanistan

75.context: Karalolu said in a speech that floods killed more than 400 people in Afghanistan, and Trkiye had already sent emergency aid by plane last week. "This train will also carry the passion, fraternity and love of Turkish people for Afghanistan," Karalolu said.AFAD Chair Memi stated that they launched the aid campaign amid Afghanistan's calls for international aid. Memi noted that Trkiye was also a leading country in delivering humanitarian aid to Gaza.The train, consisting of 43 cars, is expected to arrive in Afghanistan within two weeks. Trkiye started the "Goodness Train" series of campaigns for Afghanistan following the 2022 turmoil which saw the Taliban regain power.
75.title: Trkiye sees off another aid train for flood-hit Afghanistan
